items.text: Use Key Vault to store secrets
items.description: Use Azure Key Vault to store any secrets the application needs.  Key Vault provides a safe and audited environment for storing secrets and is well-integrated with App Service through the Key Vault SDK or App Service Key Vault References.

items.text: Use Managed Identity to connect to Key Vault
items.description: Use a Managed Identity to connect to Key Vault either using the Key Vault SDK or through App Service Key Vault References.

items.text: Use Key Vault to store TLS certificate.
items.description: Store the App Service TLS certificate in Key Vault.

items.text: Isolate systems that process sensitive information
items.description: Systems that process sensitive information should be isolated.  To do so, use separate App Service Plans or App Service Environments and consider the use of different subscriptions or management groups.

items.text: Do not store sensitive data on local disk
items.description: Local disks on App Service are not encrypted and sensitive data should not be stored on those.  (For example: D:\\Local and %TMP%).

items.text: Use an established Identity Provider for authentication
items.description: For authenticated web application, use a well established Identity Provider like Azure AD or Azure AD B2C.  Leverage the application framework of your choice to integrate with this provider or use the App Service Authentication / Authorization feature.

items.text: Deploy from a trusted environment
items.description: Deploy code to App Service from a controlled and trusted environment, like a well-managed and secured DevOps deployment pipeline. This avoids code that was not version controlled and verified to be deployed from a malicious host.

items.text: Disable basic authentication
items.description: Disable basic authentication for both FTP/FTPS and for WebDeploy/SCM.  This disables access to these services and enforces the use of Azure AD secured endpoints for deployment.  Note that the SCM site can also be opened using Azure AD credentials.

items.text: Use Managed Identity to connect to resources
items.description: Where possible use Managed Identity to connect to Azure AD secured resources.  If this is not possible, store secrets in Key Vault and connect to Key Vault using a Managed Identity instead.

items.text: Pull containers using a Managed Identity
items.description: Where using images stored in Azure Container Registry, pull these using a Managed Identity.

items.text: Send App Service runtime logs to Log Analytics
items.description: By configuring the diagnostic settings of App Service, you can send all telemetry to Log Analytics as the central destination for logging and monitoring. This allows you to monitor runtime activity of App Service such as HTTP logs, application logs, platform logs, ...

items.text: Send App Service activity logs to Log Analytics
items.description: Set up a diagnostic setting to send the activity log to Log Analytics as the central destination for logging and monitoring. This allows you to monitor control plane activity on the App Service resource itself.

items.text: Outbound network access should be controlled
items.description: Control outbound network access using a combination of regional VNet integration, network security groups and UDR's.  Traffic should be routed to an NVA such as Azure Firewall.  Ensure to monitor the Firewall's logs.

items.text: Ensure a stable IP for outbound communications towards internet addresses
items.description: You can provide a stable outbound IP by using VNet integration and using a VNet NAT Gateway or an NVA like Azure Firewall.  This allows the receiving party to allow-list based on IP, should that be needed.  Note that for communications towards Azure Services often there's no need to depend on the IP address and mechanics like Service Endpoints should be used instead.  (Also the use of private endpoints on the receiving end avoids for SNAT to happen and provides a stable outbound IP range.)

items.text: Inbound network access should be controlled
items.description: Control inbound network access using a combination of App Service Access Restrictions, Service Endpoints or Private Endpoints. Different access restrictions can be required and configured for the web app itself and the SCM site.

items.text: Use a WAF in front of App Service
items.description: Protect against malicious inbound traffic using a Web Application Firewall like Application Gateway or Azure Front Door.  Make sure to monitor the WAF's logs.

items.text: Avoid for WAF to be bypassed
items.description: Make sure the WAF cannot be bypassed by locking down access to only the WAF.  Use a combination of Access Restrictions, Service Endpoints and Private Endpoints.

items.text: Set minimum TLS policy to 1.2
items.description: Set minimum TLS policy to 1.2 in App Service configuration.
items.graph: appserviceresources | where type =~ 'microsoft.web/sites/config' | extend compliant = (properties.MinTlsVersion>=1.2) | distinct id,compliant

items.text: Use HTTPS only
items.description: Configure App Service to use HTTPS only.  This causes App Service to redirect from HTTP to HTTPS.  Strongly consider the use of HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) in your code or from your WAF, which informs browsers that the site should only be accessed using HTTPS.
items.graph: where (type=='microsoft.web/sites' and (kind == 'app' or kind == 'app,linux' )) | extend compliant = (properties.httpsOnly==true) | distinct id,compliant

items.text: Wildcards must not be used for CORS
items.description: Do not use wildcards in your CORS configuration, as this allows all origins to access the service (thereby defeating the purpose of CORS). Specifically only allow the origins that you expect to be able to access the service.

items.text: Turn off remote debugging
items.description: Remote debugging must not be turned on in production as this opens additional ports on the service which increases the attack surface. Note that the service does turn of remote debugging automatically after 48 hours.
items.graph: appserviceresources | where type =~ 'microsoft.web/sites/config' | extend compliant = (properties.RemoteDebuggingEnabled == false) | distinct id,compliant

items.text: Enable Defender for Cloud - Defender for App Service
items.description: Enable Defender for App Service.  This (amongst other threats) detects communications to known malicious IP addresses.  Review the recommendations from Defender for App Service as part of your operations.

items.text: Enable DDOS Protection Standard on the WAF VNet
items.description: Azure provides DDoS Basic protection on its network, which can be improved with intelligent DDoS Standard capabilities which learns about normal traffic patterns and can detect unusual behavior. DDoS Standard applies to a Virtual Network so it must be configured for the network resource in front of the app, such as Application Gateway or an NVA.

items.text: Pull containers over a Virtual Network
items.description: Where using images stored in Azure Container Registry, pull these over a virtual network from Azure Container Registry using its private endpoint and the app setting 'WEBSITE_PULL_IMAGE_OVER_VNET'.

items.text: Conduct a penetration test
items.description: Conduct a penetration test on the web application following the penetration testing rules of engagement.

items.text: Deploy validated code
items.description: Deploy trusted code that was validated and scanned for vulnerabilities according to DevSecOps practices.

items.text: Use up-to-date platforms, languages, protocols and frameworks
items.description: Use the latest versions of supported platforms, programming languages, protocols, and frameworks.
